when a verb group changes according to whether its subject is singular or plural. In English, this affects only the simple present, which adds an ‘s’ to the infinitive in the third person singular: ‘I want’ but ‘she wants’. The verbs ‘be’, ‘have’, and ‘do’ are irregular: ‘I am’, ‘you are’, ‘she is’; ‘I have’, ‘she has’; and ‘I do’, ‘she does’. In the sentences ‘A thorough search was carried out’, ‘It doesn’t matter’, and ‘The course has given me more confidence’, the verb groups ‘was carried out’, ‘doesn’t matter’, and ‘has given’ all agree with their subjects.

if something such as a computer or an electrical system goes down, it stops working for a period of time
to be defeated in a competition, especially in sport
to be long enough to reach a particular lower point or level
to be remembered or recorded in a particular place or way
to become less
to become less respected by someone than you were before, because of something that you have done
to become worse
to fall to the ground
to get off or out of a vehicle
to go to prison
to happen
to leave a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge, at the end of a term (=period of study) or a course of study
to move to a lower division in a sports league (=a group of teams)
to produce a particular reaction
to sink below the surface of the water
to travel to a place that is smaller or less important than the place you are leaving
to travel towards the south
when the sun or moon goes down, it moves below the horizon so you cannot see it any longer

descriptions: to become ill with a particular illness
examples: Three people in my office have gone down with the flu.

to be sold for a particular amount of money

to choose a particular thing

descriptions: be assertive and ready to initiate action. (related to the meaning 'attack')
leave a place

move clocks ahead
progress
if information goes in, you understand it
if people such as police officers or soldiers go in, they enter a place in order to take some sort of action

descriptions: to join together with someone else in order to do something such as start a business

descriptions: to say something while stammering

descriptions: to stop someone in a very unfair or cruel way from doing something
to stop something by taking determined action

descriptions: to end something bad or unpleasant by taking strong and determined action

descriptions: same as stand

to take part in an election as a candidate (=someone who people vote for) to try to defeat another candidate

descriptions: to stand somewhere and do nothing, often when you should be doing something
examples: Don’t let the boss see you standing around doing nothing.

descriptions: to let someone else have your job or position
to move to one side in order to let someone go past you

descriptions: to reach a particular level, amount etc

descriptions: to prevent someone from gaining or achieving something

to be willing to accept something that someone does

descriptions: to do someone else’s job temporarily while they are not available to do it
examples: I’ll be standing in for Peter while he’s away.

descriptions: to be easy to see or notice because of being different

descriptions: to state or show publicly that you oppose something
examples: They are not ashamed to stand out against change.

descriptions: to refuse to accept less than what you are asking for
examples: We are standing out for a fair reward for our hard work.

descriptions: to watch someone while they are doing something, usually in order to make sure that they are doing it correctly
examples: I’m fed up with him standing over me while I work.

descriptions: to begin a journey
to begin as one thing and develop into something else

used about someone’s career
examples: He started out as a salesperson before turning to poetry.

descriptions: intend, plan

descriptions: to force someone to leave a place by preventing them from getting enough food

descriptions: store or hide something in a safe place
to break something inwards

descriptions: to avoid becoming involved in something

descriptions: to use steam to separate two edges or pieces of paper that are stuck together

descriptions: avoid

descriptions: to leave an official position or job, especially so that someone else can take your place

an imperative used to tell someone to go faster, especially when driving

descriptions: chat, talk to
confront
to increase something

descriptions: to write something quickly and without taking much care

descriptions: to be easy to notice or remember because of being unusual or different
to be very obvious or noticeable
to continue doing something difficult or unpleasant to the end
to continue further than the end of a surface or the main part of an object
to push or stretch something forwards or away from you, especially a part of your body
